sections.text: #Germania omnis# a #Gallis# #Raetis#que et #Pannoniis# #Rheno et Danubio fluminibus#, a #Sarmatis# #Dacis#que mutuo metu aut montibus separatur: cetera Oceanus #ambit#, latos sinus et insularum immensa spatia #complectens#, #nuper cognitis quibusdam gentibus ac regibus#, quos bellum aperuit.

notes.text: Note the similarity to how Caesar starts B.G. (“Gallia est omnis divisa”); Tacitus writes “Germania omnis...separatur”.
the Raetians, a mountain people north of the Po, between the Danube, the Rhine, and the Lech (@L&S@).

inhabitants of “Pannonia, province of the Roman Empire, corresponding to present-day western Hungary and parts of eastern Austria, as well as portions of several Balkan states, primarily Slovenia, Croatia, and Serbia (Vojvodina)” (Britannica).
the Sarmatians (@L&S@).

the Dacians, a famous warlike people, akin to the Thracians. They occupied what is now Upper Hungary, Transylvania, Moldavia, Wallachia, Bessarabia. Subdued by Trajan, they received Roman civilization, and thence retain in part the name Rumanians (@L&S@).
surrounds.
with Oceanus.

sections.text: Rhenus, #Raeticarum Alpium# #inaccesso ac praecipiti vertice# #ortus#, #modico flexu# in occidentem versus septentrionali Oceano miscetur.

notes.text: The Rhaetian Alps extend from the valley of the Rhine river to the Brenner Pass (@Pleiades@).
Bernina Peak (13,284 feet [4,049 m]), on the Italian border, is the highest point (Britannica).
“springs” (Church and Brodribb 1942): an active translation is acceptable here.
referring to the path of the river.

sections.text: Danubius #molli et clementer# edito #montis Abnobae# #iugo# #effusus# plures populos adit, donec #in Ponticum mare sex meatibus erumpat#; septimum os paludibus hauritur.

notes.text: Beyond the Iron Gate the lower Danube flows across a wide plain; the river becomes shallower and broader, and its current slows down (Britannica).
a mountain range in Germany, the northern part of the Black Forest, in which the Danube rises (@L&S@).
iugum here is “a height or summit of a mountain, a ridge; also, a chain of mountains” (@L&S@).
“pours down” (Church and Brodribb 1942): an active translation is acceptable here.
discharges itself through six channels; cf.: “bifido meatu divisus Rhenus,” divided into two channels, Claud. B. G. 336. (@L&S@).

sections.text: Ipsos Germanos indigenas #crediderim# minimeque aliarum gentium adventibus et hospitiis #mixtos#, quia nec terra olim sed classibus #advehebantur# qui #mutare sedes# quaerebant, et immensus #ultra utque sic dixerim adversus# Oceanus raris ab #orbe nostro# #navibus# aditur.

notes.text: indirect speech; esse is gapped.
mixed with (in a racial sense).
to be carried, to ride, to come to a place upon a horse, in a carriage, ship, etc (@L&S@).
“to emigrate” (Church and Brodribb 1942); lit. to change one's home.
Tacitus's remark.
The orbis terrarum is “the circle or orb of the earth, the world” (@L&S@).

sections.text: #quis# porro, praeter periculum #horridi et ignoti maris#, #Asia aut Africa aut Italia relicta# Germaniam peteret, informem #terris#, asperam caelo, tristem cultu aspectuque nisi si #patria# sit?

notes.text: rhetorical question.
ablative of respect with corresponding adjectives.
eius (qui petit)

sections.text: Celebrant #carminibus antiquis#, quod unum apud illos memoriae et #annalium# genus est, #Tuistonem deum# #terra# editum. ei filium #Mannum# originem gentis conditoresque Manno tres filios adsignant, e quorum nominibus proximi Oceano Ingaevones, medii Herminones, ceteri Istaevones #vocentur#.

notes.text: a record of events, chronicles, annals (@L&S@).
object of celebrant, or subject of indirect speech introduced by celebrant.

The ancients, however, are agreed in stating that the Germans worshipped several divinities, among whom they mention the sun, the moon, the stars, Tuisco [sic] the ancestor of their whole race, and his son Mannus (@Smith 1845@). The best manuscripts have the spelling with ‘t’ and not ‘c’ (Stuart 1875).
The subjunctive here (in oratio olbiqua) shows that Tacitus makes the statement not on his authority, but on that of others (@Stuart 1875@).

sections.text: #quidam#, ut in #licentia vetustatis#, #plures deo ortos# #pluresque gentis appellationes#, Marsos Gambrivios Suebos Vandilios adfirmant, #eaque vera et antiqua nomina#.

notes.text: subject of adfirmant.
“the freedom of conjecture permitted by antiquity” (Church and Brodribb 1942), cf. Livy's praefatio.
[ortos esse].

sections.text: #ceterum# Germaniae vocabulum recens et nuper additum, quoniam qui primi Rhenum transgressi Gallos expulerint ac nunc #Tungri#, #tunc Germani vocati sint#: ita nationis nomen, non gentis, evaluisse paulatim, #ut# omnes primum a victore ob metum, mox et a se ipsis invento nomine Germani vocarentur.

notes.text: “on the other hand” (Church and Brodribb 1942).
gives a name to the qui earlier in the phrase.
“the tribes which first crossed the Rhine and drove out the Gauls, and are now called Tungrians, were then called Germans” (Church and Brodribb 1942).

sections.text: Fuisse #et# apud eos Herculem memorant, primumque omnium virorum fortium #ituri# in proelia canunt. sunt #illis# haec quoque carmina quorum relatu, quem #baritum# vocant, accendunt animos #futuraeque pugnae# fortunam ipso cantu #augurantur#; terrent enim trepidantve, #prout# sonuit acies, #nec tam vocis ille quam virtutis concentus videtur#.

notes.text: also, too.
(Germani) ituri; subject of canunt.
the war-cry of the Germans (@L&S@).
“It is not so much an articulate sound, as a general cry of valour” (Church and Brodribb 1942). tam...quam: correlatives.

sections.text: #adfectatur# praecipue asperitas soni et fractum murmur, #obiectis ad os scutis#, #quo# plenior et gravior vox #repercussu###

notes.text: to strive after a thing (@L&S@).
that (in order that), takes the place of ut, especially with a comparative (@Stuart 1875@).
a rebounding, reverberation, repercussion, of light, sound, wind, etc.; reflection, echo, counter-pressure (@L&S@).
The picture is that of the Germani employing their shields to amplify their voices, akin to an ancient megaphone.

sections.text: intumescat. #ceterum et# Ulixen #quidam# opinantur longo illo et fabuloso #errore# in hunc Oceanum delatum adisse Germaniae terras, #Asciburgium#que, quod in ripa Rheni situm #hodieque# incolitur, #ab illo constitutum nominatumque#; aram quin etiam Ulixi consecratam, #adiecto# Laertae patris #nomine#, eodem loco olim repertam, monumentaque et tumulos quosdam Graecis litteris inscriptos in

notes.text: “too” (Church and Brodribb 1942).
subject of opinantur.
“wanderings” (Church and Brodribb 1942); perhaps ablative of means with delatum.
An auxiliary outpost in Germania Inferior where the Ala Primae Tungrorum was based until the site was destroyed by the Batavi ca. AD 70 (@Pleiades@).
“to this day” (Church and Brodribb 1942).
founded by and named after him.
to add (@L&S@); “with the addition of” (Church and Brodribb 1942).

sections.text: confinio Germaniae #Raetiae#que adhuc extare. #quae# neque confirmare argumentis neque refellere #in animo est#: #ex ingenio suo# quisque demat vel addat fidem.

notes.text: An ancient region comprising the central Alps during Roman times, spanning parts of the modern countries of Austria, Germany, Italy, Slovenia, and Switzerland with Liechtenstein. NB the Roman administrative province of Raetia, which has its own place resource in Pleiades (@Pleiades@).
a standard formula for expressing intention.
“as [each] feels inclined” (Church and Brodribb 1942).

sections.text: Ipse eorum opinionibus #accedo# qui Germaniae populos #nullis# aliarum nationum conubiis #infectos# propriam et sinceram et tantum #sui similem# gentem extitisse arbitrantur.

notes.text: i.e., as he explained in @Ch. 2@.
the negation is put into the noun; “by no intermarriages” (@Stuart 1875@)
to mix with something; in a bad sense, to taint, infect, spoil (@L&S@). Tacitus refers to marriage with other races as a kind of corruption, in contrast with later propriam, sinceriam, etc.
Usually constructed with the genitive in pre-Augustan prose, according to @L&S@.

sections.text: unde #habitus# quoque #corporum#, tamquam in tanto hominum numero, #idem# omnibus: #truces et caerulei# oculi, rutilae comae, magna corpora et #tantum ad impetum# valida.

notes.text: condition, plight, habit, deportment, appearance of the body (@L&S@).
physical: can translate as adjective with habitus.
Latin usually connects adjectives with et where we would use commas or direct apposition.
for a sudden effort, for a brief onset (@Stuart 1875@).

sections.text: laboris atque operum non eadem #patientia#, minimeque #sitim aestumque# #tolerare#, #frigora atque inediam# #caelo solove# adsueverunt.

notes.text: iis is also gapped as a dative of possession.
thirst and heat.
tolerare depends on assuerunt (@Stuart 1875@)
the cold and want of food.
“their climate and their soil” (Church and Brodribb 1942).

sections.text: #Terra# etsi #aliquanto# specie differt, #in universum# tamen aut silvis horrida aut #paludibus# foeda, humidior qua #Gallias#, ventosior qua #Noricum# ac #Pannoniam# #aspicit#; satis ferax, frugiferarum arborum impatiens, pecorum fecunda, sed

notes.text: as a whole, in general, generally (@L&S@).
a swamp, marsh, morass, bog, fen, pool (@L&S@)
When Gaul became Roman and was divided into several parts, they were called Galliae (@Stuart 1875@).
A province of the Roman Empire at the death of Trajan (117 CE) (@Pleiades@).
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 20 C3 Pannonia (@Pleiades@).
terra is the subject.

sections.text: plerumque improcera. #ne# armentis quidem suus honor aut gloria frontis: numero gaudent, eaeque solae et gratissimae

notes.text: “not even” (@Stuart 1875@).

sections.text: opes sunt. argentum et aurum #propitiine# an irati dii negaverint #dubito#. nec tamen adfirmaverim nullam Germaniae venam argentum aurumve gignere: quis enim scrutatus est?

notes.text: propitii-ne.

sections.text: #possessione et usu# haud perinde #adficiuntur#: #est videre# apud illos argentea vasa, legatis et principibus eorum muneri data, non in #alia# vilitate quam quae humo finguntur. quamquam #proximi# ob usum commerciorum aurum et argentum in pretio habent formasque quasdam nostrae pecuniae agnoscunt atque eligunt: interiores simplicius et antiquius

notes.text: i.e. of gold and silver.
“care” (Church and Brodribb 1942).
“one may see” (@Stuart 1875@); “you may see” (Church and Brodribb 1942). s.c. [esse] in indirect speech.
another...than
s.c. Romanis

sections.text: #permutatione mercium# utuntur. pecuniam probant veterem et diu notam, #serratos bigatosque#. argentum quoque magis quam aurum sequuntur, nulla #adfectione# animi, sed quia numerus argenteorum facilior usui est #promisca ac vilia# mercantibus.

notes.text: bartering.
“milled or showing a two-horse chariot” (Church and Brodribb 1942).
The relation to or disposition toward a thing produced in a person by some influence (@L&S@).
objects of mercantibus.

sections.text: #Ne ferrum quidem superest#, sicut ex genere telorum #colligitur#. rari gladiis aut maioribus lanceis utuntur: hastas vel ipsorum vocabulo frameas gerunt #angusto et brevi ferro#, sed #ita# acri et ad usum habili, ut eodem telo, #prout# ratio

notes.text: not even (see @Ch 5@.2).
To put together mentally, etc., i. e. to gather, conclude, deduce, infer from what precedes...[w]ith ex (@L&S@).

sections.text: poscit, vel #comminus vel eminus# pugnent. et eques quidem scuto frameaque contentus est, pedites et missilia spargunt, #pluraque singuli#, atque in immensum vibrant, nudi aut #sagulo# leves. nulla cultus #iactatio#: scuta tantum lectissimis

notes.text: the same blade is fit for different forms of combat.
“each...many”.
A boasting, bragging; ostentation, display, vanity (@L&S@), cf. illa se iactet in aula Aeolus in Aen. 1.140-1.

sections.text: coloribus distinguunt. paucis #loricae#, vix uni alterive cassis aut galea. equi non #forma#, non velocitate #conspicui#. sed nec variare #gyros# #in morem nostrum# docentur: in rectum aut uno flexu dextros agunt, #ita# #coniuncto orbe# ut nemo

notes.text: a leather cuirass, a corselet of thongs (opp. thorax, a brazen breastplate) (@L&S@).
“stand out”; that attracts the attention to itself, striking, conspicuous, distinguished, illustrious, remarkable (@L&S@)
“nec equi variare gyros in morem nostrum docentur,” Tac. G. 6; so of a circular course, ring, for horses (@L&S@).
“after our fashion” (Church and Brodribb 1942).
a circular course so connected (@Stuart 1875@).

sections.text: posterior sit. #in universum# #aestimanti# plus penes peditem roboris; eoque #mixti# #proeliantur#, apta et congruente ad equestrem pugnam velocitate peditum, quos ex omni iuventute delectos #ante aciem# locant.

notes.text: “on the whole” (Church and Brodribb 1942).
Supply an impersonal head verb.
i.e., with the cavalry.
The subjects are the cavalry.
“in front of the line” (Church and Brodribb 1942).

sections.text: definitur et numerus: centeni ex singulis pagis sunt, idque ipsum inter suos #vocantur#, et #quod primo numerus fuit#, iam nomen et honor

notes.text: “take their name” (Church and Brodribb 1942).
sc. modo

sections.text: est. acies per #cuneos# componitur. cedere loco, #dummodo# rursus #instes#, #consilii quam formidinis arbitrantur#. #corpora# suorum etiam in dubiis proeliis referunt. scutum reliquisse praecipuum flagitium, nec aut sacris adesse aut concilium inire #ignominioso# fas, multique #superstites# #bellorum# infamiam laqueo finierunt.

notes.text: The wedge is better than the square, the ancient tacticians say, because it offers a point for penetrating enemy formations and gathers the leaders in a group at the front. It is easier to turn than a square because all follow the commander at the apex, “like a flight of cranes.” (@Lendon 2005@, p98)
In conditional relations as a restrictive particle, like quatenus and duntaxat, so long as, if so be that, provided that, if only (so regularly connected with the subjunctive) (@L&S@).
Tacitus begins to use the second person subjunctive rather liberally.
sc. mortua
to be over or remaining (@L&S@); here used as a noun, in the sense of having escaped from battle (Church and Brodribb 1942).

sections.text: Reges #ex# nobilitate, duces ex virtute sumunt. nec #regibus# infinita ac libera #potestas#, et duces exemplo #potius# quam imperio, si #prompti#, si conspicui, si ante aciem agant,

notes.text: To indicate the cause or reason of any thing (@L&S@).
here carrying more the sense of magis.
brave, courageous (@L&S@).

sections.text: admiratione praesunt. ceterum #neque# animadvertere neque vincire, ne verberare quidem nisi #sacerdotibus# permissum, non quasi #in poenam# nec ducis iussu, sed velut deo imperante, quem adesse bellantibus credunt.

notes.text: “neque animadvertere neque vincire nisi sacerdotibus permissum = morte multare,” to punish with death, Tac. G. 7. (@L&S@).
“as a punishment” (Church and Brodribb 1942).

sections.text: effigiesque et signa quaedam detracta #lucis# in proelium ferunt; quodque praecipuum fortitudinis incitamentum est, non casus nec fortuita #conglobatio# turmam aut cuneum facit, sed familiae et propinquitates; et in proximo #pignora#, unde feminarum

notes.text: a wood, grove, or thicket of trees sacred to a deity (L&S).
sc. militum (@L&S@).

sections.text: ululatus audiri, unde vagitus infantium. hi #cuique# sanctissimi testes, hi maximi laudatores: ad matres, ad coniuges vulnera #ferunt#; nec #illae# numerare et exigere plagas pavent, cibosque et hortamina pugnantibus gestant.

notes.text: They bear witness to the men's acts in the battlefield.
The subject switches to the men.
illae now refers to the distal subject, the coniuges.

sections.text: #Memoriae proditur# quasdam acies inclinatas #iam# et labantes a feminis restitutas constantia #precum# et obiectu pectorum et monstrata comminus captivitate, quam longe impatientius feminarum suarum #nomine# timent, #adeo ut# efficacius obligentur #animi civitatum# quibus inter obsides

notes.text: “Tradition says” (Church and Brodribb 1942).
Here used in reference to past time. See @L&S@ for more definitions.
genitive.
cf. @Caes. DBG. 6.19@.
Simply “state[s]” according to Church and Brodribb.

sections.text: puellae #quoque nobiles# #imperantur#. inesse quin etiam sanctum aliquid et providum putant, nec aut consilia earum

notes.text: Tacitus appends an attribute using quoque.
Here constructed with the dative (@L&S@).

sections.text: aspernantur aut responsa neglegunt. vidimus sub divo Vespasiano Veledam diu apud plerosque numinis loco habitam; sed et olim Auriniam et complures alias venerati sunt, non adulatione nec tamquam facerent deas.
Deorum maxime Mercurium colunt, cui certis diebus humanis quoque hostiis litare fas habent. Herculem ac Martem concessis animalibus placant.
pars Sueborum et Isidi sacrificat: unde causa et origo peregrino sacro parum comperi nisi quod signum ipsum in modum liburnae figuratum

docet advectam religionem. ceterum nec cohibere parietibus deos neque in ullam humani oris speciem adsimulare ex magnitudine caelestium arbitrantur: lucos ac nemora consecrant deorumque nominibus appellant secretum illud, quod sola reverentia vident.
